description: From Middle English belyen, beliggen, from Old English belicgan, bilicgan (“to lie around, surround, hedge in, encompass”). Equivalent to be- (“around, by”) +‎ lie (“to be positioned”).

verbs.description: belie (third-person singular simple present belies, present participle belying, simple past belay, past participle belain)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete, of an army) To surround; beleaguer.

description: From Middle English belyen, beleoȝen, from Old English belēogan (“to deceive by lying, be mistaken”), from Proto-West Germanic *bileugan (“to belie”). Equivalent to be- (“about”) +‎ lie (“to deceive”). Compare Dutch beliegen (“to lie about, tell lies”), German belügen (“to tell a lie”).

verbs.description: belie (third-person singular simple present belies, present participle belying, simple past and past participle belied)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To tell lies about. [from 13th c.]
(transitive) To give a false representation of. [from 17th c.]
(transitive) To contradict, to show (something) to be false. [from 17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: contradict, give lie to, give the lie to
Her obvious nervousness belied what she said.

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To call a liar; to accuse of falsehood. [from 17th c.]
(transitive, rare) To fill with lies; to lie to.
(transitive, perhaps nonstandard) To conceal the contradictory or ironic presence of (something).
examples: His calm demeanor belied his inner sense of guilt.

entries.meaning: (transitive, perhaps nonstandard) To show, evince or demonstrate (something) to be present, particularly something deemed contradictory or ironic.
